ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND BAN ON IMPORT OF LIVE PIGS



    1. Mr R. Ravindran asked the Minister for National Development if he will give an update on the measures taken by his Ministry to prevent the spreading of Japanese Encephalitis and when we can expect the import of live pigs into Singapore.

    2. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Minister for National Development (a) what is the total number of pork sellers, pork-based and pork-related traders and stallholders who are affected by the ban on the import of live pigs into Singapore;

Column: 1176

and (b) whether there are other forms of assistance being considered to help these traders and stallholders, apart from the one-month rental waiver for pork stallholders and factories.

    3. Dr Lee Tsao Yuan asked the Minister for National Development whether, in the recent viral outbreak, the illnesses of the abattoir workers and those involved in the trading of pigs could have been avoided, and how serious are their illnesses.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos 1, 2 and 3 together?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Thank you. Sir, first, let me give a quick summary of what happened. Following the outbreak of the Japanese Encephalitis (JE) in Malaysia, the Primary Production Department (PPD) monitored the situation closely and kept in close contact with their counterparts in Malaysia.

    As the situation deteriorated in Malaysia, PPD progressively took additional measures. PPD carried out serological surveys on imported pigs to confirm that there was no active JE infection in imported pigs. Mosquito control measures were intensified. Abattoir workers were advised to be vaccinated.

    When it was reported that a Hendra-like virus has been isolated from human cases in Malaysia, PPD stopped the import of all pigs from Malaysia and closed our abattoirs. As an added precaution, PPD also banned the import of dogs, cats, horses and other mammals from Malaysia. These measures are still in place today.

    PPD and other agencies in the Ministries of the Environment and Health are still closely monitoring the situation. The measures put in place have been effective in not only ensuring that JE did not occur in Singapore but also that the outbreak of

Column: 1177

the previously unknown Hendra-like virus has been contained.

    Next, let me touch on the impact of the ban. The ban on the import of live pigs into Singapore has affected the following groups of people directly:

    i. 22 live pig importers;

    ii. 759 pork stallholders (647 pork stallholders in markets managed by HDB, and another 112 by ENV);

    iii. 98 meat processing plants licensed by PPD. These plants, employing about 860 workers, are involved in the cutting and deboning of pork, meat roasting and the manufacturing of Chinese and Taiwanese sausages, and sweet meat (bak kua); and

    iv 75 food factory tenants in HDB industrial estates. 11 of these are meat processing plants licensed by PPD.

    To assist those directly affected by the ban and with little recourse to substitutes, both HDB and ENV have waived the rent for pork stalls in HDB and ENV markets for one month. As for the 75 food factory tenants, they either received a waiver of one-month rent or a half-a-month (if they are not completely dependent on fresh pork supplies), and one month service and conservancy charges given by the PAP Town Councils. Both HDB and ENV would review the concessions given towards the end of the one-month rent free period and may extend the waiver, if necessary.

    With regard to the resumption of live pig imports, we will only allow it when we are certain and confident that they are safe for the Singaporean public.

    When pigs can be imported from Malaysia will depend on how successfully the current disease outbreak is controlled. We will resume imports from Johor only when the area can be declared to be a disease-free zone according to international standards. We do not foresee this taking place in the immediate future.

Column: 1178



    The pig farms in Pulau Bulan, Indonesia, were not affected by the JE or Hendra-like virus outbreak. However, now that we know of the existence of the Hendra-like virus in our region, we have to take special precautions. First, Pulau Bulan must be free from the Hendra-like virus or Nipah virus. PPD has recently inspected Pulau Bulan and did not observe any clinical evidence of the disease there. PPD has also taken blood samples of the pigs and sent them to CDC, Atlanta, USA, for Nipah virus testing. When we receive the test results to confirm that the farms and the island are free from the disease, then we can be sure that Pulau Bulan is indeed free. Following that, we will do regular blood testing every two weeks to exclude the Nipah virus infection. We will also maintain strict viral security at the farms, ie, the pigs can only be brought into the farms with PPD's approval. We will insist on the maintenance of strict hygiene and control of vectors such as mosquitoes, bats which are potential Nipah virus vector and rodents.

    In addition, PPD will insist that the following measures be taken:

    All pigs, from the weaning stage, must wear ear tags that are serially numbered and approved by PPD as a means of identification. Each consignment of pigs must be isolated for two weeks prior to exporting to Singapore. Every consignment of pigs must be inspected by a PPD veterinary officer to ensure that the pigs are properly identified and are healthy before loading into barges for transport to Singapore. Every consignment of pigs must again be inspected for health and identification on arrival in Singapore. In the short term, PPD will station its own veterinary officers full-time at Pulau Bulan to check production and health records, closely monitor the farms for any sign of infectious diseases and ensure that all pigs are properly tagged and accounted for. In this way, we can be confident that any pig imported into Singapore from Pulau Bulan will be disease-free.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan asked whether the illnesses could have been avoided. Let me

Column: 1179

explain that our actions taken have been effective in preventing the JE outbreak from occurring in Singapore.

    However, the illnesses affecting the local abattoir workers have been confirmed to be due to the previously unknown Hendra-like virus. Prior to 19th March 1999, there were no reports from Malaysia that indicated that another virus other than JE may be involved in the human cases there.

    Dr Lee also asked about the seriousness of the illnesses. Eleven abattoir workers were affected by the viral illness. Of these, 9 had infection of the brain and 2 had infection of the lungs. One of the patients died and 9 have been discharged from hospital as at 12th April 1999. The remaining patient who is still in hospital has improved and is in stable condition. The patient is expected to be discharged from hospital later this week.

    The illness caused by the Hendra-like virus is serious and can be fatal. Prompt action by the various Government agencies has limited the number of infections. We were unfortunate to have one fatality but we are thankful that the rest have recovered.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, may I ask the Minister if we need to diversify our sources of food import as much as possible from now on and whether he will promote chilled fresh meat as the preferred choice of meat in Singapore, and if anything can be done and has been done to facilitate this?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, the outbreak of the Nipah virus is of serious consequences to us as far as our pig imports are concerned. Even with all the precautions that we have taken, the supply from Pulau Bulan can only meet 20% of our consumption. At the same time, we do not see the supply from Johor or the rest of Malaysia coming in in the immediate future. So our main sources will have to be from other countries in the form of chilled or frozen pork. This is the business environment

Column: 1180

that we are communicating to those in the trade. We are having discussions with the pork stallholders association and explaining to them that they have to adjust to this new environment and the Government would help them to adapt to this new condition.

    At best, Pulau Bulan can supply us 20%. The supply from Malaysia will not be forthcoming, and even if it is forthcoming in the following months or years, it will continue to have a question mark because of the outbreak of the Hendra virus. We will always have to look out for possible outbreaks. For reasons of food safety and hygiene and diversification of our sources, we feel that we have to move to chilled and frozen pork from a wider variety of sources and we will be working with traders in the trade on how to adjust to providing chilled and frozen pork to Singaporeans.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, the Minister has said that the PAP Town Councils have given a waiver of service and conservancy charges to all stalls selling pork. I would like to report to this House that the Potong Pasir Town Council has done likewise.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): Sir, may I ask two questions? The first is: is pork, which has been infected with the Nipah virus and the Hendra-like virus, safe for eating? The second question is: how can we ensure that if we eat pork we would not suffer from eating pork precisely since there was a case of pigs being smuggled into Singapore recently?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: We have said this repeatedly. First of all, pigs which are affected by JE, the pork is safe for consumption. JE is not transmitted from human to human and it is not transmitted from eating pork. The evidence so far shows that this is the same for the Hendra-like virus or the Nipah virus, ie, you will not contract the virus from a human being or from eating pork. The evidence so far shows that those who were down with the disease were in direct contact with a diseased pig. That is the main source of infection.

Column: 1181



    Mr Simon S C Tay (Nominated Member): Sir, may I ask the Minister, given that there is a Hendra-like virus involved, race-horses which have visited Malaysia in the last six months may be susceptible to this. What measures is the Ministry taking to make sure that these horses are not infected?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, since 19th March 1999, we have banned the movement of race-horses between Malaysia and Singapore. These horses are kept in quarantine. They have been tested for infection of the virus. The Turf Club in Singapore has also systematically set out to test all the horses in Singapore as a precautionary measure. Only when we are confident that the horses are free from the disease will we admit the horses into Singapore.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Will the Government assist existing fresh pork sellers to transfer to the sale of chilled and frozen pork?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: We are in discussion with the association and stallholders. We think it is necessary and important for the stallholders to switch to facilities that can allow them to sell frozen or chilled pork. I think Lianhe Zaobao has reported that a stallholder in Marine Parade market has renovated his stall to sell chilled pork. It shows a very innovative and entrepreneurial approach to the situation. The chiller facilities cost less than $6,000. The Government, through HDB and ENV, will facilitate all this conversion. We will provide the necessary power supply. We will upgrade all our wet markets so that all the stalls can be similarly upgraded.

    Mr Simon Tay: Sir, can I ask the Minister about the wild boars in Pulau Ubin which have been ordered to be killed? Given that we are taking the approach of testing race-horses, might not the same approach be taken for these wild boars, that they be hunted down, anaesthetized and then tested, rather than being shot on sight?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: It is a pleasure to be talking about pigs rather than HDB flats! But I am afraid wild boars do not quite

Column: 1182

come under my Ministry. These are wild boars in Pulau Ubin and from what I read in the newspapers, there seems to be an over-population of wild boars and MINDEF is taking this opportunity to cull the wild boars. If the wild boars can be tested for the disease, then I hear a comment from behind me that they would not be wild boars. They would be tamed boars!

    Mr Gerard Ee (Nominated Member): Sir, could the Minister clarify whether other meats are exposed to the danger of these viruses, such as beef, chicken and duck?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: There is no evidence that the virus has spread to any other meat.

Column: 1182

OCCUPANTS OF FORMER ISTANA KAMPONG GLAM AND ADJACENT LOT 53
(Resettlement benefits)


    4. Mr Ahmad Mohd Magad asked the Minister for Law whether the occupants of the former Istana Kampong Glam and the adjacent Lot 53 will receive resettlement benefits and what is the Government's plan with respect to the Sultan Hussain Ordinance.

    The Minister for Law (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, the first part of the Member's question concerns resettlement benefits of the occupants. In the case of the former Istana Kampong Glam, those occupants living there at the cut-off date of 13th March 1999 will be considered for resettlement benefits under prevailing resettlement policy.

    As for Lot 53 which was acquired under the Land Acquisition Act, the normal process is for Land Office to make a compensation award based on vacant possession, in which case the issue of resettlement will not arise. However, if the landowner does not deliver vacant possession, an award on an encumbered basis will be made instead, in which case the occupiers of the property will be cleared under existing resettlement policy.

Column: 1183



    The second part of the Member's question asks about the Government's plan with respect to the Sultan Hussain Ordinance.

    There are some 79 beneficiaries who are receiving payments under that Ordinance. Many of them are not even in Singapore. Of those in Singapore, only a few of them, about 14, actually live in the former Istana Kampong Glam.

    The position of the Sultan Hussain Ordinance has been clarified by Government in the past. In particular, the former Minister for National Development, Mr S Dhanabalan, set out the position clearly in this House on 12th March 1991, and I quote an extract:

    'In 1896, towards the end of the last century, there was a dispute among the family of Sultan Hussain as to who was the successor to the Sultanate and to the estate, ie, the Kampong Glam Estate. This matter went to court and in December 1897, the Court of Appeal ruled that there was no one who could claim to be the successor. The estate, therefore reverted to the Crown. It became State land and it was no longer subject to the treaties which previously affected it.'

    Therefore, the Kampong Glam Estate including the former Istana has been State Land since 1897.

    The British Government then enacted the Sultan Hussain Ordinance in 1904. The intention of the Ordinance was to take care of the financial needs of the family at that time of the late Sultan Hussain who were described by the then British Governor as "very improvident people". The Ordinance provided for annual payment of monies to the family of the late Sultan Hussain pegged to the income derived from the Kampong Glam Estate. These payments were not intended to be in perpetuity but were intended to be made only to "the family of the late Sultan Hussain" at the time the Ordinance was enacted. Nevertheless, for historical reasons, annual payments were continued to be made by subsequent Governments all these 100-odd years. This has led to a very unsatisfactory situation. Firstly, while the number of beneficiaries has steadily increased, the payments are getting

Column: 1184

smaller as the income from which the payments are made has diminished. Secondly, in future the payments would become even smaller over time as the number of beneficiaries increases. In view of these factors and with the recently announced new conservation projects for Istana Kampong Glam and the adjacent building as a Malay Heritage Centre, Government has decided that it is timely to review the scheme of payments under the Ordinance.

    The Government has therefore decided on a new scheme of payments. Firstly, we will increase the actual payments to $350,000 per annum. Secondly, this new sum of $350,000 per annum will be maintained for a fixed period of 30 years starting from this year to be distributed among the existing number of beneficiaries in the same proportion to the total annual payment that they are receiving at present. This revised fixed income will be a substantial increase of more than 10 times the actual annual payment to the beneficiaries at present which amounts to about $29,231. In addition, if any beneficiary wishes, the Government will allow him the option of receiving a lump sum payment up-front which would be equivalent to the present value of the future stream of payments under the new scheme.

    This new scheme will apply to all existing beneficiaries regardless of where they presently live. Those beneficiaries who are now occupants at the former Istana Kampong Glam will benefit from this new scheme of payments in addition to whatever resettlement benefits they may get as described earlier.

    This new scheme is an equitable way of meeting the interests of the existing beneficiaries. The alternative of maintaining the status quo will mean progressively diminishing amounts of payments.

    The Land Office will contact the beneficiaries individually to explain the new scheme to them.

    Mr Ahmad Mohd Magad (Pasir Ris): I would like to thank the Minister for the

Column: 1185

very comprehensive answer. I would just like to know whether this would include the beneficiaries who are resident overseas.

    Prof. Jayakumar: Indeed, because under the present scheme, all the 79 beneficiaries are entitled to the payments, so the revised scheme would also apply to them.

    Encik Ibrahim Bin Othman (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, what about those present beneficiaries who do not want to take the lump sum? Will they draw that sum after 30 years?

    Prof. Jayakumar: This new scheme, as I said, is for a period of 30 years, which we think is more than reasonable. It should take care of most of their adult life. It cannot obviously be in perpetuity because the intention was never to be in perpetuity.

Column: 1185

VENTURE CAPITAL FUND FOR TECHNOPRENEURS
(Criteria for eligibility)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Zulkifli bin Baharudin -

    5. To ask the Minister for Trade and Industry, in respect of the Venture Capital Fund for technopreneurs, (a) what are the criteria for eligibility; (b) whether there are any other schemes to help technopreneurs have better access to loans; and (c) whether there are plans to have more liberal policies to deal with problems of business failures and bankruptcies.

    Mr Simon Tay: Question No. 5, Sir.

    The Second Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Venture capital is smart money. All venture capital funds will subject projects seeking their investment to careful analysis. They will assess the value of the intellectual property, the risk involved and the expected rate of return on investment. Ultimately, the success of the funds will depend on their willingness to assess industry potential and take calculated risks.

Column: 1186



    Government venture capital funds must also be governed by the same principles of risk-return. Through EDB and NSTB, the Government helps to provide seed funding for new start-ups. Projects invested by these funds are subject to standard 'due diligence' analysis.

    The Technopreneurship 21 Committee will consider other schemes to help technopreneurs gain better access to loans. Our support of technopreneurs should extend beyond financial assistance. It is equally important to give adequate support in other areas, such as providing business guidance and developing market intelligence. To illustrate, NSTB's recently launched $10 million Technology Incubator Programme not only provides seed funding for technopreneurs, it also engages individuals and companies as incubator managers to nurture local start-up companies. Our technopreneurship development strategy must be comprehensive, covering not just financing but also education, facilities and regulation.

    One of the most important requirements in building up a technopreneurship sector in Singapore is a change in mindset. We need a culture rich in innovation and enterprise. We need to reduce our social cost of failure and encourage those who fail to try again. In this respect, our rules and regulations will be reviewed under the T21 initiative, with a view to removing the obstacles for risk-taking. A private sector committee has been set up to review our existing rules and regulations in order to facilitate technopreneurship. The initial recommendations of the Committee would be announced by the third quarter of this year.

    Mr Simon Tay: May I ask the Minister, when speaking about standard due diligence, does this mean that the fund will do exactly the same as the banks and other financial institutions do and therefore what advantage is there in Government setting aside a special fund for technopreneurs?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: It is important we adopt the best practices

Column: 1187

which obtain in Silicon Valley and in America. The purpose of starting this new fund is to help create an indigenous venture capital sector in Singapore. Mr Inderjit Singh told me that he once had a project which could not be funded in Singapore and that he had to go to Taiwan where there was so much expertise in this area to get the financing. We should have such a developed sector in Singapore so that those who are starting start-ups here would be able to get local financing.

MANAGEMENT-LEVEL WORKERS
